content: quote: (CNN) -- Dr. Sanjay Gupta, CNN's chief medical correspondent, has withdrawn his name from consideration as surgeon general of the United States, an administration official said Thursday. "Sanjay Gupta was under serious consideration for the job of surgeon general," the official said in an e-mail. "He has removed himself from consideration to focus more on his medical career and his family. We know he will continue to serve and educate the public through his work with media and in the medical arena." Sources said in January that Gupta met then-President-elect Obama in Chicago, Illinois, in November to discuss the post. Gupta has declined comment. <more> "http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/03/05/gupta.surgeon.general/index.html I thought this was a done deal.
quote: (CNN) -- Dr. Sanjay Gupta, CNN's chief medical correspondent, has withdrawn his name from consideration as surgeon general of the United States, an administration official said Thursday. We know he will continue to serve and educate the public through his work with media and in the medical arena." Sources said in January that Gupta met then-President-elect Obama in Chicago, Illinois, in November to discuss the post. Gupta has declined comment. <more> "http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/03/05/gupta.surgeon.general/index.html
reply: I thought this was a done deal.

content: Yes, he saved a Marine and an Iraqi child over there when he was reporting for CNN. In the Marine's case, he had the medics sterilze a power drill so he could do his brain surgery. It was an emergency. He told Larry King that 4 yrs in D.C. and away from the practice of surgery would diminish his skills too much. He's a very young man so I don't blame him. He will make an outstanding surgeon general in 25 yrs or so.
reply: Yes, he saved a Marine and an Iraqi child over there when he was reporting for CNN. In the Marine's case, he had the medics sterilze a power drill so he could do his brain surgery. It was an emergency. He told Larry King that 4 yrs in D.C. and away from the practice of surgery would diminish his skills too much. He's a very young man so I don't blame him. He will make an outstanding surgeon general in 25 yrs or so.

content: quote: Originally posted by badmac933: quote: Originally posted by vsibaby: Yes, he saved a Marine and an Iraqi child over there when he was reporting for CNN. When Gupta was reporting for CNN? The answer to your question is "yes" ... but vsibaby is incorrect on one point: quote: When reporting for CNN on a U.S. Navy medical team in Iraq in 2003, Gupta unexpectedly became part of the story when he was called upon to conduct emergency brain surgery on a 2-year-old Iraqi boy shot by U.S. Marines when he was in a car that did not stop at a checkpoint. The boy did not survive. "http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jan/07/busy-gupta-performs-brain-surgery-reports-cnn/ I mention that for accuracy only, not to take anything away from Gupta who I greatly admire. As vsibaby noted, this is one of the reasons why: quote: In 2003, Gupta traveled to Iraq to cover the medical aspects of 2003 invasion of Iraq. While in Iraq, Gupta performed emergency surgery on both U.S. soldiers and Iraqi civilians. Gupta was embedded with a Navy medical unit at the time. A Marine named Jesus Vidana suffered a severe head injury, and the Marines asked for Gupta's assistance because of his background in neurosurgery. Vidana survived and was sent back to the United States for rehabilitation. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanjay_Gupta
quote: Originally posted by badmac933: quote: Originally posted by vsibaby: Yes, he saved a Marine and an Iraqi child over there when he was reporting for CNN. When Gupta was reporting for CNN?
reply: The answer to your question is "yes" ... but vsibaby is incorrect on one point: quote: When reporting for CNN on a U.S. Navy medical team in Iraq in 2003, Gupta unexpectedly became part of the story when he was called upon to conduct emergency brain surgery on a 2-year-old Iraqi boy shot by U.S. Marines when he was in a car that did not stop at a checkpoint. The boy did not survive. "http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jan/07/busy-gupta-performs-brain-surgery-reports-cnn/ I mention that for accuracy only, not to take anything away from Gupta who I greatly admire. As vsibaby noted, this is one of the reasons why: quote: In 2003, Gupta traveled to Iraq to cover the medical aspects of 2003 invasion of Iraq. While in Iraq, Gupta performed emergency surgery on both U.S. soldiers and Iraqi civilians. Gupta was embedded with a Navy medical unit at the time. A Marine named Jesus Vidana suffered a severe head injury, and the Marines asked for Gupta's assistance because of his background in neurosurgery. Vidana survived and was sent back to the United States for rehabilitation. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanjay_Gupta
title: Dr. Sanjay Gupta Withdraws from Consideration as Obama's Surgeon General Nominee

content: Conyers tries to keep Gupta from surgeon general post By TODD SPANGLER • FREE PRESS WASHINGTON STAFF • January 8, 2009 Read Comments(24)Recommend(4)Print this page E-mail this article Share this article Del.icio.us Facebook Digg Reddit Newsvine Buzz up! WASHINGTON – House Judiciary Chairman John Conyers is circulating a “Dear Colleague” letter in Congress asking for help to discourage President-elect Barack Obama from nominating Novi native, CNN editor and neurosurgeon Sanjay Gupta to be his surgeon general....... "http://www.freep.com/article/20090108/NEWS15/90108095/1009/NEWS07"
reply: Conyers tries to keep Gupta from surgeon general post By TODD SPANGLER • FREE PRESS WASHINGTON STAFF • January 8, 2009 Read Comments(24)Recommend(4)Print this page E-mail this article Share this article Del.icio.us Facebook Digg Reddit Newsvine Buzz up! WASHINGTON – House Judiciary Chairman John Conyers is circulating a “Dear Colleague” letter in Congress asking for help to discourage President-elect Barack Obama from nominating Novi native, CNN editor and neurosurgeon Sanjay Gupta to be his surgeon general....... "http://www.freep.com/article/20090108/NEWS15/90108095/1009/NEWS07"
title: Dr. Sanjay Gupta Withdraws from Consideration as Obama's Surgeon General Nominee

content: Seems to me, Congressman Conyers is "under investigation" (for quite some time) due to complaints that he failed to pay taxes on a Villa in the Carribean Islands. My point is anyone he opposes; likely, I'd support! Other than seeing him of TV; I know very little about Dr Gupta. As Surgeon General, I think his annual pay would be around $109K; plus Government Quarters and the other Military fringe benefits. I conclude he would be losing money IF HE TOOK THE SG Job! There seems to be a "Lot of Internal Battles" among Democrats about who will get the Administration Cabinet Positions and the PAST Selections of Obama really has not "thrilled" most Americans. Of course, I think this Presidency is a diaster and who Obama chooses as Surgeon General won't change my overall view! From A Proud Vietnam Veteran
reply: Seems to me, Congressman Conyers is "under investigation" (for quite some time) due to complaints that he failed to pay taxes on a Villa in the Carribean Islands. My point is anyone he opposes; likely, I'd support! Other than seeing him of TV; I know very little about Dr Gupta. As Surgeon General, I think his annual pay would be around $109K; plus Government Quarters and the other Military fringe benefits. I conclude he would be losing money IF HE TOOK THE SG Job! There seems to be a "Lot of Internal Battles" among Democrats about who will get the Administration Cabinet Positions and the PAST Selections of Obama really has not "thrilled" most Americans. Of course, I think this Presidency is a diaster and who Obama chooses as Surgeon General won't change my overall view! From A Proud Vietnam Veteran

content: 1. Dr. Gupta was never formally appointed; his name was floated as one of those being considered for appointment, and he was widely seen as the front-runner. 2. Dr. Gupta is not a neurologist. He is a neurosurgeon. Big difference.

More like there are few intelligent people any who want to put up with the Gotcha political games that have been getting worse for the last couple of decades with each party using the process to make political points and get revenge. A Lot of good people are deciding that you have to put up with to much crap to make public service possible. Hey...I can't argue with that!

title: Dr. Sanjay Gupta Withdraws from Consideration as Obama's Surgeon General Nominee

content: Conyers tries to keep Gupta from surgeon general post By TODD SPANGLER • FREE PRESS WASHINGTON STAFF • January 8, 2009 Read Comments(24)Recommend(4)Print this page E-mail this article Share this article Del.icio.us Facebook Digg Reddit Newsvine Buzz up! WASHINGTON – House Judiciary Chairman John Conyers is circulating a “Dear Colleague” letter in Congress asking for help to discourage President-elect Barack Obama from nominating Novi native, CNN editor and neurosurgeon Sanjay Gupta to be his surgeon general....... "http://www.freep.com/article/20090108/NEWS15/90108095/1009/NEWS07"

title: Dr. Sanjay Gupta Withdraws from Consideration as Obama's Surgeon General Nominee

content: Seems to me, Congressman Conyers is "under investigation" (for quite some time) due to complaints that he failed to pay taxes on a Villa in the Carribean Islands. My point is anyone he opposes; likely, I'd support! Other than seeing him of TV; I know very little about Dr Gupta. As Surgeon General, I think his annual pay would be around $109K; plus Government Quarters and the other Military fringe benefits. I conclude he would be losing money IF HE TOOK THE SG Job! There seems to be a "Lot of Internal Battles" among Democrats about who will get the Administration Cabinet Positions and the PAST Selections of Obama really has not "thrilled" most Americans. Of course, I think this Presidency is a diaster and who Obama chooses as Surgeon General won't change my overall view! From A Proud Vietnam Veteran

content: 1. Dr. Gupta was never formally appointed; his name was floated as one of those being considered for appointment, and he was widely seen as the front-runner. 2. Dr. Gupta is not a neurologist. He is a neurosurgeon. Big difference.
reply: 1. Dr. Gupta was never formally appointed; his name was floated as one of those being considered for appointment, and he was widely seen as the front-runner. 2. Dr. Gupta is not a neurologist. He is a neurosurgeon. Big difference.
title: Dr. Sanjay Gupta Withdraws from Consideration as Obama's Surgeon General Nominee
